talk.start.para: .- This bill is entitled, " a bill to make necessary provision for carrying out a plan agreed on by the Commonwealth and 'he States for meeting the grave financial emergency existing in Australia, reestablishing financial stability, and restoring industrial and general prosperity."
- A bill to bring in the millennium !

- But it deals with only a part of the problem that confronts the Commonwealth. The Premiers' plan has as its object the reduction of expenditure by all the Australian Governments, the reduction of interest rates on public loans, the securing of additional revenue, the reduction of bank interest rates, and the reduction of interest rates on private mortgages. Since this bill provides only for the reduction of Commonwealth expenditure, it is obvious that it relates to only a portion of the plan which, in its turn, deals with only a portion of the problem which confronts the people of Australia. .

speech.para: I agree that the reduction of government expenditure contemplated by the bill is necessary as a condition precedent to the re-establishment of public credit. This expenditure must be reduced because of the obvious failure of the budget to produce the expected results. In his speech on the financial rehabilitation plan, the Treasurer (Mr. Theodore) admitted that the Commonwealth revenue was short of expectations to the extent of approximately Â£21,400,000, less about Â£4,000,000 from the sales tax. There is a deficiency in customs of Â£14,000,000, and a shortage in direct taxation of Â£4,000,000. No previous Commonwealth budget has failed so disastrously. When it was introduced it was known that the position was extraordinarily difficult, and yet from the day of its operation it failed, and the position has become worse from month to month. In short, the budget was a striking tribute to the incapacity and incompetence of the Government, and in particular of the Treasurer.

The supporters of the Government - ' those of them that are left in this House and in the press - have vociferously declared from day to day that at this particular juncture the Ministry, and the Treasurer especially, should be exempt from parliamentary or other criticism. Honorable members on this side are willing to assist the Government in carrying out this plan, because we regretfully acknowledge that it is necessary if we are to overcome the difficulties that beset us. But I am speaking for the Opposition as a whole when I say that we refuse to accept the view that the Government, the Treasurer, or any other member of the Ministry, is to be exempt from criticism at the present time. Our support of the plan, which the increasing seriousness of the financial position of the Commonwealth has forced the Government to adopt, must not be interpreted as support of the Government itself .

talk.start.para: - When does the honorable member intend to move a no-confidence motion ?
- We shall do that so soon as we are satisfied that all honorable members now supporting the Government are prepared to vote in accordance with their real opinions.
- Move a no-confidence motion on this measure, and we will support it.

- My particular reason for making this statement is that, when speaking on the financial rehabilitation plan, the Treasurer said that had the legislation proposed by the Government been passed, and the Government been able fully to operate its financial proposals, there would have been no need to attack pensions or the basic wage. The honorable gentleman also went on to Bay that he believed in the plan which had been propounded at the Premiers Conference in February last. From this we are entitled to assume that, although the plan agreed upon at the conference in Melbourne a few weeks ago is now before the House, the Government still believes in the financial proposals submitted by the Treasurer at the previous conference in. February. Those proposals, I remind honorable members, included legislation for a fiduciary issue - an attempt ito settle our difficulties by politicallycontrolled inflation. For that reason, I wish to make it quite clear that, while the Opposition supports the plan now before the House, it maintains its uncompromising hostility to any proposal for politically controlled inflation. I say this because certain honorable gentlemen appear to believe that members in opposition now entertain such a kindly spirit for the Government that they are willing to feed out of its hand. I wish to make it quite plain that that is not the case; that in supporting this bill, we do not surrender our right of criticism within or outside this chamber.

speech.para: This plan is introduced as a means of meeting the grave financial emergency existing in Australia, of re-establishing financial stability, and of restoring industrial and economic prosperity. It was only in February last that the Treasurer said again what he had often said before. and his statement is printed on page 28 of the report of the February conference as follows: -

quote.para: If by merely reducing expenditure, we could rectify the position, and distribute over the whole of the community the burden that must be borne, that would be a simple expedient, and well within our power; but unfortunately the serious economic problem that exists to-day cannot be solved by those means.

speech.para: And ho went on to speak of the reduction of interest, and the desirability of bringing it about.

talk.start.para: - That was the difficulty then.

- This plan provides for a reduction in expenditure, and agreements have been made with the banks for a reduction of interest. We all know that the difficulties with which Australia and other nations are confronted are due largely to world . causes, and honorable members on this side of the Hou3e know that the imminence and probable operation of those world causes were pointed out to this Parliament, and to the people of Australia, by the last Government early in 1929. The present Government refused to pay any attention to those warnings, and the difficulties due to world causes have, in my opinion, been gravely accentuated by its policy, or lack of policy.

speech.para: The present plan is the result of a decision of the Loan Council and the Premiers Conference made in February last. The decision was then strongly opposed by the Treasurer, because he again propounded his policy of a fiduciary note issue. Now, if we are to give his words their face value, he says that there would be no need for any of the proposals in this plan if his February proposals had been adopted. I cannot at this stage review the whole of the Government's disastrous policy, but I point out that the Government's inflation policy has in itself had a great deal to do with the development of the present unfortunate position. It has contributed to the present lack of confidence in governments and government finance. As recently as the 18th of June last, in the speech to which I have referred, the Treasurer, speaking, we may assume, on behalf of the Government, professed himself as still an advocate of the inflationary policy previously endorsed by the

Government. Subsequent to the February conference, a fiduciary notes bill was introduced into this House, and after its rejection, the Prime Minister said that the Government would go on to a double dissolution on that issue. That statement has not, in explicit terms, been withdrawn. The present plan cannot work alongside a policy of inflation. The two things are contrary, and entirely opposed to each other. There is no surer way of aggravating the difficulties which exist to-day than to pursue the Government's February policy, which apparently has now been reaffirmed. The surest way of reducing pensions and wages is to bring about inflation under political auspices. I go so far as to say that one of the conditions of the restoration of prosperity is the abandonment of this policy of politically controlled inflation. Until the Treasurer spoke the other day I thought that the Government had abandoned it, not that it was keeping the inflation policy up its sleeve, as it were, for possible production on a future occasion. I believed this because, when the Leader of of the Opposition (Mr. Lyons), Senator Pearce, and myself attended the Premiers Conference in Melbourne, this question was raised, and the Leader of the Opposition said that any conversion scheme would, he feared, be gravely prejudiced if there were still a prospect of inflation as a government policy. He asked the Prime Minister whether he was prepared to make a declaration of the Government's policy in regard to the matter. At page 132 of the report of the conference, the Prime Minister is reported to have replied to the honorable member for Wilmot in these words -

talker.name: LYONS, Joseph Aloysius
Mr Lyons, my last sentence was

talk.start.para: - " If a satisfactory plan can bc secured it should be the financial policy of every government."

speech.para: I had thought that this was the financial policy, and the whole relevant financial policy, of this Government, and that, the financial stability of Australia, was no longer threatened by a policy of inflation. I should like to obtain from the Government some statement modifying, or, 1 hope, contradicting, what the Treasurer has said, because I fear that if the Government is going on with inflation as a policy there is small hope of economic restoration in Australia.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member is trying to give a new significance to my words. He has spoken three times since I made that speech, but has not made any previous reference to what I said.

- I received the reprint of the Treasurer's speech, I think, on Thursday last. I have read it carefully since then, and I find in it the statement that the Treasurer " does not want anybody to run away with the idea that the Government is making an admission that the policy propounded and placed 'before the Premiers Conference in February is unsound." I take that as meaning that the Treasurer maintains that the policy was sound, but that, unfortunately, the Government was prevented from carrying it out. That appears to me to be a fair interpretation to place upon his words.
- Is the honorable member attacking our honesty in regard to the present plan?

- The success of the present plan will, I fear, be compromised so long as the statement stands that the Government still believes in currency inflation as a policy. The prosperity of the Commonwealth is seriously prejudiced by statements such as that. It is most unfortunate that the Government should take the opportunity of the introduction of this measure to re-announce its belief in the policy of a fiduciary note issue.

speech.para: This bill deals only with a portion of what is necessary to restore prosperity in Australia. Other things obviously must be done. The tariff has to be reconsidered from the point of view both of revenue - which is Â£14,000,000 down - and of protection. I repeat that, in my opinion, Australia's overgrown system of industrial regulation has fastened manacles and fetters upon our industries, which make it extremely difficult for our goods to compete in the world's markets. I add that it is useless for us to fix wages so high that they cannot be paid, and that, consequently, thousands are thrown out of work. Our whole system of industrial regulation must be reconsidered before we oan get on a sound footing again.

I accept the necessity for the reduction of governmental expenditure pro posed in this bill. I do so under each of the headings mentioned - salaries, wages and pensions, including the maternity allowance, which, although not a pension, s an allied payment, and also invalid, old-age and Avar pensions. I. welcome the proposed small saving in connexion with the High Court, and I agree that there must be a reduction in bounties. I agree with the proposals contained in this measure, not, as I have already said, because I like them, but because, with the Treasurer, I believe that they are imposed upon us by an inexorable and inescapable necessity. We cannot afford to continue to make these payments on the basis on which we have been paying them. These payments were fixed on a prosperity basis, and we cannot afford to keep them up in the present difficult time.

The difference between our economic position to-day and that of a few years ago is reflected in the index figures of retail prices contained in the last Quarterly Summary of Australian Statistics, for March, 1931. Taking the Statistician's index figures, which are generally accepted as indicating the cost of living - although I am aware that they are more useful for comparative than for absolute purposes - we find on page 74 a statement showing the average amount necessary in the periods specified to purchase certain commodities in each capital city, and in all the capital cities averaged. The figures show that food, groceries, and housing, which cost, on the average, Â£1 during the five-year period from 1923 to 1927, cost only 17s. lOd. for the first quarter of 1931. That indicates that there has been a drop in costs since 1927.

talk.start.para: - On a few articles.

- I have said that the figures are useful principally for the purposes of comparison. The Statistician's figures give a fair indication of prices; I do not say that they are an absolute guide, or that they are the measure of the diminution of costs in any one household. They are, however, the only standard of comparison that we have. A substantial reduction in costs is going on day by day, and the reductions proposed to be made will further reduce costs. To the extent that the reductions now proposed correspond to the reduction in the cost of living, they are not reductions in the values received by individuals, so far as such individuals spend their money in purchasing the items upon which these index figures are based. The position is that to-day 17s.10d. buys articles of the value that it required 20s. to buy during the period 1923-27, or 19s.10d. in 1921.
- Is clothing included?
- No. One of the criticisms levelled against the index figures is that they do not include the cost of clothing. The reasons for the omission have been given many times.

speech.para: Not only must there be a reduction in many items of our expenditure corresponding to the reduction in the cost of living, but also, owing to the very real diminution in the national income, we must be content with less this year than satisfied us in 1925, when it cost 20s. to buy what 17s.10d. will purchase to-day. In order to put Australia on a sound basis, and to bring down the cost of living, the reduction of expenditure must be greater than the reduction in the cost of living; otherwise we shall at best remain stationary. Accordingly, I do not complain of, although I cannot say that I am pleased to be associated with, these reductions.

talk.start.para: - They conform to views expressed by the honorable gentleman about nine months ago.

- Yes. Excepting in the case of pensions, it will befound that this bill bears a marked resemblance to proposals which I made, as Leader of the Opposition, in July of last year when speaking on the budget.
- The honorable gentleman did not then advocate any reduction of interest.

- I repeat that, generally, this bill, excepting insofar as it proposes to reduce pensions, corresponds to suggestions which I made last July. The Postmaster-General (Mr. A. Green) says that I did not then say anything about a reduction of interest. That may be so. I certainly have never suggested direct legislative action to reduce the interest of which complaint has been made - particularly bank interest and interest on fixed deposits and overdrafts.

speech.para: I am glad that wise counsels have prevailed, and that such legislative action is not now proposed, but that the reduction of interest is being left to agreements between the banks and the governments, or to declarations of policy by the banks. I have always said that it is impossible to control the effective rate of interest by any legislation, whatever. I repeat that statement to-day, and shall give my reasons for it. It is obvious that, so long as there is a possibility of purchasing 5 per cent. Commonwealth stocks at Â£60, a man who buys them obtains a return of more than 5 per cent. on his investment. Legislative action to reduce interest tends to depress the price of stocks, and, therefore, to increase interest. No legislative action can prevent the holders of stock from selling them for the best price they can get; and, therefore, no legislative action can determine interest rates in the general market.

talk.start.para: - On the honorable member's premises the plan must fail, unless the banks agree to do what the honorable gentleman says ought not to be done.

- Not at- all. With the conversion loan scheme, the agreement of the banks to reduce interest, and the hoped-for restoration of confidence, which will increase the prices of government stocks, the interest rate ought to go down. That I shall welcome. ButI am unable to approve legislation introduced with the avowed object of depressing interest rates, because that will necessarily bring about the lowering of prices of stock, and, therefore, increase interest rates. It is in the hope that the scheme will not work that way that I am prepared to support it.
- It will work out in a way which will be the very opposite of that desired by the honorable gentleman.
- I sincerely hope that it will not. Obviously, there is room for difference of opinion with regard to the various proposals of the bill, but these can best be dealt with in committee.

speech.para: I began by stating the divergence of the opinions of myself and the Treasurer. Let me- adjust the balance by approving very strongly what was said by the honorable gentleman in his recent broadcast speech, as reported in the press on the- 3rd instant. In that statement the Treasurer expressed, clearly and accurately, the reasons which prompted the introduction of this measure. The report reads -

quote.para: The time had come for vigorous action - to take stock of the damage and to set about building up and repairing. Australia had suffered an enormous loss due to the depression. As a country we could not escape that loss. We could not get rid of it in any way. We had to face it ourselves. Any one who thought that old wage rates could continue in these circumstances was living in a world of illusion.

speech.para: Those, unfortunately, are the facts, and the bill is a genuine effort to deal with the situation.

My criticism of the Government, particularly in relation to its monetary policy, with which I began my speech, does not extend to the details of this measure. I recognize that in bringing down the bill, Ministers have faced a task which would be a difficult and unpleasant one for any administration. I shall not, by meticulous criticism of this or that detail, do anything to lessen the chance of carrying into effect the substance of theproposals embodied in the measure.

Mr.LAZZARINI (Werriwa) [3.45].- The bill before the House, like its associated measure with which we have dealt, and those which are to follow, will play its part in further depressing the country economically. My colleagues and I again place on record our opposition to these proposals, and are prepared to leave the future to decide whether we are right or wrong. This and the other measures represent the action of a government that has been stampeded, and speaks eloquently of the scattered thoughts of those who sponsor them.

The present depression is not peculiar to Australia. It exists in almost every other country in the world, and is continuing, mainly because those in charge refuse to face stern realities, and to get to the root of the trouble. I havehere a copy of a letter that was sent from Canada to the Premier of New South Wales, which discloses that matters are just as bad in that country as they are here. The Government, Ministers, and economists, in that country are behaving similarly to those of the same class here; they are running around ineffectually, endeavouring to prove that black is white, and vice versa. The letter, which is from the United Farmers of Canada, Saskatchewan Section, is short, interesting and apposite, is as follows: -
Dear Sir, -

One of the lodges of our organization, namely, the Fennell Hall Local Lodge, at North Battleford, Saskatchewan,passed a resolution at a meeting held recently, requesting me to express to you appreciation for the human stand taken by yourself recently, when, according to press reports, you stated publicly that you would not take money from labour and farmers to be given to bondholders. The members of our organization realize that it requires a man of courage and strong convictions to take such a stand against the capitalistic exploiters, and they wish to advise you that your . action is being noted in far-off Canada.

We, the farmers of Western Canada, are living in troublesome times. Most of us are facing bankruptcy; our land is covered with mortgages. The prices of farm products is the lowest in history, which, of course, makes it impossible to pay either taxes or even interest payments on our loans.

Our streets are crowded with unemployed men and women, and to cap it all, the powers that be, i.e., both provincial and federal governments seem to be going around in circles holding conferences, and accomplishing very little by way of a solution to the economic problem.
It is, therefore, a great pleasure for us to convey our most sincere appreciation to you for the commendable stand which you have taken.
Wishing you every success,
Yours very truly,
Frank Eliason,
Secretary.

This afternoon the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Latham) endeavoured to prove that there is still an " opposition " in the House. I do not wish to be thought ungenerous, but I believe that there was a suspicion of stage management about the whole affair. It was an endeavour to make the people believe that a sham fight at least was going on in this chamber between what was at one time a Labour government, and its conservative opponents. I guarantee that after this plan has been eventually bludgeoned through by the votes of honorable members opposite, if the Government manifests a desire to send the Treasurer (Mr. Theodore) to Great Britain, the Leader of the Opposition will do his utmost to bring about the fulfilment of that desire. This bill provides for, among other things, the reduction of the basic wage of Commonwealth public servants.

The Treasurer proposes arbitrarily to reduce that wage to Â£3 10s. a week. He cannot justify such' a reduction with any figures or any data at his disposal. It will be the lowest wage operating in any State of the Commonwealth, as well as in the Commonwealth itself. This, the parliamentary fixation of wages, is an action that all parties in this House said that they would never tolerate.

Of ali the measures that are to give effect to the Melbourne plan, this is the one under which the real sacrifices are to be made. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been repeating, with nauseous frequency, the cry, "equality of sacrifice ". Let us analyse- some of the probable effects of this bill, so as to see whether there will be equality of sacrifice. I had a general idea of the meaning of the term " equality of sacrifice ", but out of curiosity I consulted "Webster's dictionary, from which I learned that the definition of " equality " is " a state of being equal ; a sameness, an evenness ". Turning to "sacrifice" I found that it relates, in a number of forms, to devotion to a deity. The deity before whose high altar these sacrifices are to be made is Mammon. The term is also defined as the giving up of something with loss and suffering.

Let us apply the definitions of these two terms to the reductions that are to he made under this bill. Assuming that ministerial allowances are equal in the case of all Ministers, each of these gentlemen receives an allowance of Â£1,177 per annum. To that must- be added the Â£1,000 per annum which he receives as a member.

talk.start.para: - It has been reduced to Â£S00.

- Allowing for that deduction, each Minister receives Â£1,977. When the proposed reductions have been made he will receive approximatly Â£1,500, which is equal to Â£30 a week, compared with the 17s. 6d. a week that is to be paid to the old-age pensioner. That is one example of equality of sacrifice! Then these gentlemen can recoup themselves to a large extent by way of ministerial expenses. I know well that when travelling they do not spend anything like the amount that they are allowed. Therefore, as I said in a former speech, what they lose on the merry-go-round they can make up on the razzle-dazzle. The old age pensioner has not that opportunity.

speech.para: I come to those highly-paid gentlemen who are Justices of the High Court of Australia. I have read the bill carefully, and I cannot see in it any provision for the reduction of their salaries. Reference is made to their pensions, and it is proposed to reduce the cost of the High Court by limiting the amount of travelling done by it; but, so far as I can see, the salaries of the judges are not mentioned.

talk.start.para: - They are not to unreduced. If the honorable member will read section 72 of the Constitution lie will learn the reason.
- When I interjected during the Treasurer's speech he said that they were to bo reduced.

- -I am acquainted with the provisions of the Constitution. I have not had an opportunity to read the whole of the report of the Premiers Conference held in Melbourne, but. according to the press, when the Premier of New South Wales asked whether judges' salaries were to be reduced be was answered in the affirmative.
- It cannot be done byordinary legislation.

- The Chief Justice of the High Court is paid Â£3,500 a year, or Â£70 a week. I invite honorable members to compare that with the 17s. 6d. a week that is to be paid to an old-age pensioner, and to say where is the sameness, the evenness of the sacrifice. The other judges of the High Court each receive Â£3,000 a year, or Â£60 a week. J Judged according to their value to the community, I suppose that many old-age pensioners have, during their lifetime, in pioneering and developing this country, performed incomparably greater services than have been, or ever will be, performed by these gentlemen.
- Did not the honorable member, assist to place two superfluous members on the High Court Bench ?

- That has nothing to do with this case. I would put three more there if I could get men who would not slash the' wages of the workers of this country, and I would consider their services cheaply obtained. There is no humbug as to where I stand. I am prepared to say what I think with regard to these matters, either here or elsewhere. I would deal with these wage-slashers as they deserve, had I the power to do so.
- When has the High Court dealt with the question of wages?

- It deals with appeals. Furthermore, all the trouble to-day in the ranks of the members of the Waterside Workers Federation is due to the action of the High Court, and was made possible because one man, who was put there for a certain purpose, did not do his job properly.
- That is a very serious reflection upon the High Court.

- Then I withdraw it, without waiting to be called on by Mr. Speaker to do so. I should have made none of these remarks had not honorable members opposite made what they considered were smart interjections. Those interjections do not frighten me.

speech.para: Then there is the Governor of the Commonwealth Bank, who receives Â£5,000 per annum and Â£3 3s. for every day that he travels on the business of the bank away from it3 head office. His salary is to be reduced to Â£3,778, or Â£76 a week. Some of our old-age pensioners have done work of a much more valuable nature than that of the present Governor, or management, of the Commonwealth Bank. It is largely on account of the conservative policy adopted by this institution that Australia is in its present condition.
The Director-General of Postal Services managed to earn only a few hundred pounds a year before he found Australia to be a Utopia for him.

talk.start.para: - Seven hundred pounds per annum.

- He now gets Â£4,000 per annum. He will be required to give up Â£1,000, and come down to about Â£60 a week. Many of the secretaries to departments draw Â£2,000 a year. Their salaries will be reduced to about Â£1,550, which will still leave them about Â£30 a week,, as against the 17s. 6d. a week for old-age pensioners.
- What about members?

- I had intended to refer to members' salaries in a few moments, but I will deal with them now. Members are to be reduced from Â£1,000 to Â£800 a year, or about Â£16 a week. Compare that with the old-age pensioners' pittance of 17s. 6d. a week !

speech.para: I now come to the proposal to deduct ls. a week from the allowance made to invalid pensioners in hospitals and sanatoria. This Government will soon be taking the pennies from the blind men's boxes. The inmates of hospitals and sanatoria have been granted 5s. Cd. a week in the past, to enable them to purchase such comforts as pipes and tobacco. I have received a letter of disgusted protest from inmates of the Waterfall Sanatorium, which is in my electorate. They cannot understand a Labour government taking ls. a week from their paltry allowance. Most of these men have worked for the greater part of their lives in mines, or have been engaged in excavation work in connexion with the sewerage system of Sydney, but they are now thrown upon the industrial scrap-heap. Most of them are dying with lung trouble. No cloaking over an act of this kind by words, at which the Treasurer is an adept, will ever remove the shame of reducing the allowance of these men. Is this to be their reward for contracting a deadly disease while helping to provide one of the greatest services that engineering science can give to a nation? This one act destroys every vestige of claim that members of this Ministry have to be called Labour men, o.- even decent democrats. It leaves them in the rut of Tory conservatism, and the sooner the electors have an opportunity to destroy the Government, the better it will be for the country, and for the good name of the Labour movement.

An attack is to be made on the home of the old-age pensioner. A home valued >at Â£810 at the present time is not a palace; it can " -vide only bare necessities. But this Government proposes to reduce the value of the home in the possession of which an aged person is entitled to receive the pension, without a special deduction to Â£500. Any value above that sum is to be regarded as property in the possession of the pensioner, and a corresponding reduction of the pension is to be made. The Treasurer was sufficiently generous not to include a pensioner's furniture and personal clothing in assessing the value of his home. The reduction is too great, considering how high land values are, particularly in the cities. If the old home, in which an aged couple have reared their family, is worth over Â£500,and if they do not wish to lose their pension, all sentiment must be thrown to the wind; they must sell out, and buy a cheaper dwelling. They have no court of appeal, except the Valuer-General.

talk.start.para: - Yes, they have.

- The honorable member who interjects should not try to salve his conscience in this matter. One time a radical and a rebel, he now supports this stuff that the Treasurer brings down. He ought to be ashamed of himself.
- Tell the truth.

- If the honorable member further interjects, he will get all that he is apparently looking for. Many pensioners will be compelled to sell out, and buy cheaper homes, which will enable the spieler, the land agent, and the " go-getter " to make an unfair profit over the transaction at the cost of the pensioner. This reduction is an everlasting disgrace to a Cabinet that still has the audacity to call itself a Labour Ministry. When I think of the traditions of Labour, and the fight that we have had in the past to obtain the conditions that the workers enjoy to-day, I am utterly ashamed of this Government.
- The Labour party did very little toward the provision of old-age pensions.

- I claim to have done more for the Labour movement, without remuneration, during half of my lifetime, than the honorable member did for the section that he represents, during the period when he was striving to gain a seat in this House. I am prepared to welcome any investigation regarding my services in the interests of the Labour movement.
- I ref erred to the Labour party, and not to the honorable member personally;

- The Labour party was responsible for the payment of the original old-age pension. The pension was first provided by the Reid Government in 'New South Wales, which, as every one knows, was put in office and kept there for the specific purpose of introducing the first pensions legislation. The Lyne Government, which was in office prior to the Reid Government, refused to introduce a bill to provide for the payment of the pension, and when Mr. Reid was asked by a Labour deputation whether he would do so if Labour supported an administration led by him, he said that he would "give the pension as a Christmas box ", and he did so. Honorable members opposite who deny to the Labour party the real credit for the establishment of our old-age and invalid pension system, talk with their tongue in their cheek.
- Did the Labour Government ever provide for an increase in the old-age and invalid pension?

- Anti-Labour governments have increased the pension, but only to the extent of the bare increases in the cost of living. On every occasion when an increase has been proposed, the Labour party has endeavoured to make it greater than the Government of the day desired. When the Bruce Page Government, for instance, proposed an increase of 2s. 6d. to make the total 17s. 6d., the Labour party endeavoured to make the increase 5s. We always went one better than our opponents. Yet a. government which dares to call itself a Labour Government, is now proposing a reduction in the rate of pension.
- Why not put the Government out of office?
- We would do so in five minutes if we could on this issue. We have had no opportunity to put the Government out of office since it has taken this dastardly action.
- The honorable member must withdraw the word " dastardly ".

- I withdraw it. ] would not have used it except for the interjection of the honorable member for Parkes. By the taking of this action the Government has left every principle and tradition of the Labour party behind it. Working men who could ill afford it. contributed their pennies, threepenny bits, and sixpences to the fighting fund for the election which resulted in the return of Labour to power with the largest majority any single party has ever had; and I am ashamed to say that the reward that is being given for their sacrifices is the betrayal of the principles of the Labour party. There are many former stalwarts of the industrial movement at present in the Waterfall Sanitorium who are to-day watching with amazement the destruction of all the ideals of the Labour party.
- What point is the honorable member trying to make?
- I am attacking the Government for its dastardly act in reducing the amount of pension payable to our old-age and invalid pensioners.
- The honorable member must withdraw the word " dastardly and I ask him not to use it again.

- I withdraw the word. The members of the group to which I belong will not attempt to amend this bill, for they regard every provision of it as anathema. We shall oppose the measure at every stage. The bill, which is negative in every respect, strikes a vital blow at some of the sacred principles and traditions fdr the maintenance of which the Australian Labour Party has fought since its inception.

speech.para: It is proposed to reduce the maternity allowance from Â£5 to Â£4, and to discontinue the payment of it altogether in cases where the income of the applicant and her husband exceeds Â£260 per annum. The Prime Minister himself gave reasons why it will be difficult to give full effect to this provision. He referred to the cost of making inquiries to discover whether the income of the applicant was within the limit of Â£260 per annum. In my opinion, it will cost nearly as much to make these inquiries as it would cost to pay the allowance to all applicants, irrespective of income. I object to this provision because the inquisitorial formula which must be observed in respect to the granting of old-age and invalid pensions will be made to apply in the case of applications for the maternity allowance. I can make no complaint about the asking of these numerous questions, because the law requires it; but I consider that all citizens, irrespective of their income, should be entitled to the pension. If the Government felt that it was necessary to do so, it could impose extra taxation in the case of persons with substantial incomes, and so ensure the return of the money to the Treasury.' But while the law stands as it does, it is undoubtedly necessary to ask a certain number of questions of the applicants for the pension. I object, however, to the asking of these questions during the very period in a mother's life when she should not be disturbed and upset by such inquiries. The introduction of thi3 principle into our maternity allowance legislation is entirely wrong, and no government responsible for. it is entitled, for a single moment, to be regarded as a Labour government. This Government should no longer pretend to stand for the idealism and principles of the Labour movement.

The Treasurer indulged in more characteristic word-spinning when he referred to the payment of living allowances to certain war pensioners. If the . honorable gentleman had dealt openly and straightforwardly with the subject, he .would have said that the Government intended to discontinue the payment of these allowances in certain cases; but he took the more round-about course, and said that it intended to regard the allowances as part of the pension. This, of course, means that certain war pensioners will be deprived of their allowances. The honorable gentleman could not have justified the straight-out discontinuance of the payment of these allowances, so he did not say in plain language what he intended to do.

talk.start.para: - The returned soldiers themselves made certain proposals.

- Certain conservative individuals who control various soldier organizations have made certain proposals. I do not think that the rank and file of the returned soldiers had ah opportunity to express an opinion.

speech.para: I object to the proposals of the Government for the reduction of the salaries and wages payable to persons in its employ. In my opinion, the action of the Government in this regard is entirely out of accord with the arbitration policy of the Labour party. Labour fought an election about eighteen months ago on the arbitration policy of the Bruce-Page Government. That Government dared to interfere with our arbitration system, and, in consequence, was defeated on the floor of the House by the Labour party, with the assistance of certain former government supporters, or semi-supporters. An appeal was subsequently made to the people, and Labour was returned to power with an overwhelming majority. The party has since been wrecked, and the policy on which it was returned has be.come a thing of shreds and patches. This Government has shown its utter incompetence and inability to control the affair's of the nation.

talk.start.para: - At one moment honorable members opposite thirst for the blood of the Government, and at the next they fight for it like mad mullahs. When this measure is enacted, Commonwealth public servants and others in the employ of the Commonwealth Government will lose the privileges which they now enjoy under the arbitration system, privileges of which the members of this Government said they would be deprived if the Bruce-Page Government were returned to power at the last general election. As a result of the action which the Government proposes to take in interfering with awards of the Arbitration Court and in laying its hands upon the basic wage, a precedent is being established which will be followed by the capitalistic institutions, and, particularly, the financial institutions, of this country. The Government is adopting a principle which may be useful when we have a " dinkum " Labour Government in office. . This Government has adopted a policy which even antiLabour Governments have not had the courage to introduce. It has remained for this alleged Labour Government to interfere with the basic wage, to reduce the invalid and old-age and war pensions, and the conditions under which the maternity allowance is to be paid. The Government has adopted the policy which conservative judges of the Arbitration Court would not tolerate. I hope that when a real Labour Government occupies the treasury bench-
- That will not be for twenty years.

- The honorable member is as inaccurate in that calcula tion as he was when he said that he would win the Warringah seat by 10,000 votes, and squeezed in with only a few votes to spare. This bill is a scandal, a disgrace and a degradation-
- Those words are unparliamentary, and must be withdrawn.
- I withdraw them. In conclusion, I shall repeat what I said in speaking to the second reading of another measure - that this is Labour's day of degradation and disgrace.

.- The members of the Country party will support the 'Government in carrying out the decisions reached at the conference of Commonwealth and State Ministers held in Melbourne, which are embodied in this bill. We regard this measure as in the nature of a draught of nauseous medicine, which Australia must take as a first step towards its financial recovery, and we think that if we spurn this bitter draught, it will intensify the malady. A sick child is not restored to health by a weak or indulgent nurse who gives heed to the complaint of the child that the doctor's medicine is nasty, instead of insisting that the medicine shall be swallowed. I hope that when a vote is taken on the second reading of this bill there will not be in this chamber too many whose attitude will be that of the weak and indulgent nurse.

speech.para: Eight months ago, I spoke in this chamber of the need foi- taking this medicine in much the doses the Government is now prescribing.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member advocated a 30 per cent, reduction.

- Nothing of the kind. I advocated a 20 per cent, reduction on all controllable expenditure, and I further said that if the Government did not take its courage in its hands we might get into such an unsatisfactory financial position that even a bigger sacrifice would be inescapable. I said that such a reduction was inevitable, and I believe that had the treatment been undertaken sooner it would have been better for the patient. Eleven precious months have passed since, the previous conference of August last, and during that time we have been financially slipping backwards at a tremendous rate. Even if the reductions in Commonwealth and State expenditure agreed upon at the last Melbourne conference are made, we shall still not restore budgetary equilibrium. For the financial year just closed, the deficits of the Commonwealth and the States amount to over Â£30,000,000, almost half of which will be the deficit of the Commonwealth. We are also told that if the Commonwealth and States were to continue their expenditure as at present for the current financial year, there would be a further deficit on the 30th June next of approximately Â£40,000,000. If the reductions proposed are made, the position will be only partially met. \ Quorum formed.] The effect of the reductions which are being made will only bridge, to a comparatively small extent, the tremendous gap which lies between our present revenue and our expenditure. Some honorable members have said that if success attends the proposals of Mr. Hoover for an international war debt moratorium, and Australia is by this means saved Â£3,000,000 of interest on war debts, certain reductions need not bo made. I point out that with all the reductions proposed, even with the benefit of the remission of war debt interest, which I trust we shall get, and notwithstanding heavy additional taxation, we shall still have many millions of pounds to add to last year's deficit of Â£30,000,000 for the Commonwealth and the States.

speech.para: To those who say that the Public Service reductions should be confined entirely to- the most highly-paid officers, whom some describe as the " tall poppies," a most striking answer is to be found in the graph which has been circulated and which gives the relative proportions of the different salary groups to the total salaries bill of the Commonwealth. It shows how futile it would be to bring about the 20 per cent, reduction of public service expenditure agreed upon at the Premiers Conference in Melbourne recently by reducing only the salaries of the higher-paid officers. If all the officers in the Commonwealth Public Service drawing over Â£500 a year worked for nothing the result would be a saving of less than 10 per cent. in the Commonwealth salaries bill. If we adopted the ideas of some of the misguided gentlemen who sit in the corner opposite, and of the notorious Premier of New South Wales, whose disciples they are, and chopped off all salaries over Â£500 a year, the result in the Commonwealth service would be a saving of only 2^ per cent., whereas the Premiers Conference decisions require a saving of eight times that amount. The graph also shows that Commonwealth Public Service salaries up to Â£399 a year account for 77.7 per cent, of the total salaries bill, and salaries up to Â£499 for 90.1 per cent. Salaries of Â£500 and over represent less than 10 per cent, of the total. When, as a nation, we are compelled to save in millions, it must be obvious that every one must bear a share, and that it is impossible to obtain a sufficient reduction by dealing only with the higher paid officials in the Commonwealth Public Service. If the man on the basic wage outside the Public Service has been compelled to lose 10 per cent, of his wages in actual cut, plus a greater amount than that due to the reduced cost of living index figures, making the total reduction he has suffered over 20 per cent., surely no one inside the Service should regard himself as sacrosanct.

I feel sure that there is no honorable member who does not regret very much indeed the necessity to reduce invalid and old-age pensions. Less than eight years ago the pension rate was 15s. a week. At that time revenues were abundant, prices were higher than they are to-day, and the cost of living was dearer. The country could then afford to pay a higher rate, and the Bruce-Page Government felt fully justified in raising the rate from 15s. to 17s. 6d. a week. And two years later, when revenues were still good, and the cost of living still comparatively dear, the same Government again raised the pension to the level of Â£1. Now, however, when the nation is immeasurably poorer than it was a few years ago, and the cost of living has, to a certain extent, come down, a reverse proceeding on the part of the Government of the day is inescapable. The money cannot be found to continue at the old rate. But what will make it easier for the old people is the fact that the cost of living is to-day lower than it was in 1923 when the pension was increased from 15s. to 17s. 6d. a week. In that year the index figure for food, groceries, and housing, the- three factors upon which wages are fixed, was 1805, whereas for the first quarter of this calendar year it was 1546. There has been a considerable drop.

talk.start.para: - What does the honorable member regard as a considerable drop?

- A drop from 1805 to 1546, which means that with the present reduction the pensioner will be better off than he was when he was formerly receiving 17s. 6d., although he may not be quite so well off as he is to-day with a pension of Â£1.

- During the course of his speech the honorable member for Werriwa (Mr. Lazzarini) claimed for the' party to which he belongs a very substantial part of the credit for the granting of old-age pensions.
- The honorable member cannot deny it.

- I did not wish to claim for any particular party special credit for the granting or increasing of pensions, but since the honorable member for Werriwa (Mr. Lazzarini) seems to claim some special credit in that regard for his own party, I shall give him in brief the history of old-age pension legislation - how these pensions came to be paid, and when the different increases were made. Legislation providing for Commonwealth old-age and invalid pensions was first proposed by a Liberal Government, which went out of office before that legislation could be put into effect. The Labour Government which succeeded held office for only a short period, and it also had no time to put pension proposals into operation. Another Liberal

speech.para: Government then took office, and provided for an old-age pension at the rate of 10s. a week. That rate of pension continued until 1916, when just prior to going to the country the Labour Government then in office increased the pension to 12s. 6d. a week. Subsequently, when the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) was Prime Minister, and during his absence in Great Britain, the Right Honorable W. A. Watt, who was then acting Prime Minister, moved to increase the rate of pensions from 12s. 6d. to 15s. a week. Two more increases in the pension were made during the administration of the Bruce Page Government. Although, therefore, honorable members opposite may claim some credit for giving or increasing the' pension, what has been done is substantially to the credit of those on this side of the House.

The honorable member for Werriwa referred to the judiciary and the salaries of its members. I understand that there are certain constitutional difficulties in the way of reducing those salaries, but, if that be the case, I hope that these legal gentlemen will offer to make a sacrifice in conformity with that made by other sections of the community. The remarks of the honorable member for Werriwa about the cost of the judiciary came from a quarter from which they were not to be expected, because only a little while ago 'that honorable member was a member of the caucus which compelled the present Government, practically at the point of the party bayonet, to appoint two additional High Court judges, although the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General both considered that at that time they would be superfluous. Honorable members in the ministerial corner who are complaining about the payment of Â£60 a week to members of the judiciary, were responsible for adding to that expense by insisting on unnecessary appointments being made when the Prime Minister was in Great Britain. Those honorable members, if they refresh their minds by reading the cables sent by the Prime Minister, will know that the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General pleaded with the caucus not to make these appointments until their return. The Prime Minister pointed out in his cables that the appointments were being made just at the beginning of a long vacation, when they were less necessary than at any other time. The honorable member for West Sydney (Mr. Beasley) and the honorable member for Werriwa must take their full share of responsibility for those appointments, and for adding unnecessarily to the cost of the judiciary.

speech.para: I come now to Part VI. of the bill. It was with great relief that most honorable members heard, on Friday last, the announcement of the Prime Minister of the Government's acceptance of the plan unanimously adopted by the Returned Soldiers Pensions Committee. Some of the representatives on that committee will, doubtless, be subjected to criticism from some of their league members, for agreeing to a reduction of any kind, and I take this opportunity to pay a tribute to the members of that committee for the splendid public spirit that they have shown in their desire to help this country in a time of difficulty. The soldiers previously helped this country during a crisis, and now they are repeating their good work. If honorable members were, without exception, prepared to show the same courage in facing the criticism of their constituents, it would make it much easier for this Government to do the right, though unpopular, thing. I hardly thought it possible that a million pounds could be saved without affecting the soldier's own pension or that of the orphan and the widow, and I am particularly glad that that has been found to be practicable. Of course, that does not mean that the soldier pensioners, as a whole, will not. suffer some reduction, because a large percentage of them are married men, and will, therefore, suffer some sacrifice because of the reduction in the pensions of their wives and children. It has been said that the unmarried soldier will escape any sacrifice, since his individual pension is not to be reduced, but the figures show that a large proportion of the unmarried soldiers are badly incapacitated. Indeed, it is possible that their incapacity has largely prevented them from marrying. A large proportion of them are so badly incapacitated, that they are unable to undertake the responsibility of a wife and family. We owe a great deal to these men, and no one desires that their pensions should be reduced. I hope that this Soldier Pensions Committee, in its efforts to save a further Â£281,000, will be helped by those who are in a position to do so, by surrendering the whole, or a portion, of their pensions for the time being. If that is done the sacrifices made by those men will render unnecessary further sacrifices by those who are less able to afford them.

Part VIII. of the bill relates to the reduction of bounties. In the present, circumstances of Australia, the proposed reductions are justified, but in respect of the manufacturers of sulphur and wire netting, who are protected by 'bounties in lieu of duties, I hope that the reduction of bounties will not be offset by an increase of duties. Sulphur is an essential constituent of superphosphate, and wire netting is necessary to the man on the land, and if duties are imposed on these commodities the manufacturers' share of the general sacrifice will be passed wholly on to the primary producers. Part VIII. would have been much more complete if it had provided for a general reduction of duties as well as of bounties. The Treasurer (Mr. Theodore) said on Friday last, in justification of the 50 per cent, reduction of the bounty on gold, that the exchange rate on gold to-day is Â£30 10s. per cent. That argument is equally applicable in favour of a reduction of duties, because the manufacturer has that protection in addition to the ordinary duties. He is getting also the benefit of lower wages, lower rates of interest on bank overdrafts, and high duties, at a time when lower duties would suffice. A few weeks ago, I brought to the notice of the Prime Minister (Mr. Scullin) the tremendous gap existing between the average prices of primary products and manufactured goods respectively. Taking the prices in 1911 as 100, the average prices of primary products in January last was 117 and of manufactures, 188. I said then that I did not believe that the rehabilitation of Australia's trade was possible until that gap had been closed to some extent. The Prime Minister asked me whether my figures included the tremendous advantage which the export industries are at present enjoying owing to the exchange. I replied that I was satisfied that they did. I have since found confirmation of that statement, because, by April, many months after the exchange had risen to its present rate, the figure for primary products had risen from 117 to 119, and for secondary products from 188 to 193. No general rehabilitation of industry and re-employment of our people can take place until something is done to bring about a greater conformity of the prices for primary and secondary products. So long as the present gap between the two remains, the depression in Australia will continue. The effect of it is that the primary n roducer, to exchange his goods for manu- factured products, has to part with 60 per cent, more than previously. Therefore he is unable to buy the same volume of the products of the secondary industries as he did formerly, and I see no hope of employment being found throughout Australia in the secondary industries until they can afford to sell at prices which those engaged in the exporting industries can afford to pay. So strongly do I feel regarding the need for lowering duties and reducing prices in conformity with the reductions in salaries and the general decrease of the purchasing power of the people, that I would propose an amendment in committee but for the limitations imposed by the title of the bill, which declares that the bill is " to make necessary provision for carrying out a plan agreed on by the Commonwealth and the States ". An amendment relating to tariff duties would not come within that title, and therefore would be ruled out as irrelevant. The only alternative open to me is to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading, but I shall not do that, because I and the members of my party have no desire to help the Lang faction in this chamber to destroy the bill. "We believe that this legislation, unpleasant though it is, must be enacted, and as a party, we are willing to accept our share of responsibility for doing something which undoubtedly is unpopular, but we believe, is right and inescapable, and something without which Australia cannot possibly be restored to prosperity.

Whilst we shall support the bill, I wish to make it perfectly clear that I consider that this portion of the plan, and indeed the whole plan agreed to by the Melbourne conference, is incomplete, because it does not provide for relief in respect of the undoubtedly high cost of production, both primary and secondary. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Latham) referred to restrictions on industry which add tremendously to production costs. I agree entirely with what he said. We have to remove some of the shackles from both the primary and the secondary industries before industry can again become buoyant and work be found for the unemployed. The export trade should not continue to be entirely the responsibility of primary production. "We should remove the handicaps from industry to such an extent as to enable the big natural industries to play their part in the export trade, and thus help the country to meet its overseas obligations. It is too much to expect one branch of production to get Australia out of its difficulties, while another great branch, which is growing from year to year, is left to the enjoyment of a highly sheltered market without any responsibility in regard to the load of overseas obligations. We cannot, however, expect the secondary industries to take their proper part in the export trade until action is taken to remove some of those conditions which clog their wheels and make production unnecessarily expensive. The members of the Country party regret the omission from the bill of what we regard as a vital part of any plan of rehabilitation, and hope at a suitable opportunity to get from the House an expression, of opinion in regard to the reduction of tariff duties. An amendment to the motion for the second reading might only help those whom I believe to be the enemies of Australia to defeat the bill. Therefore, we shall support the measure, although we regard it as an incomplete plan for the economic rehabilitation of Australia.

talk.start.para: .- I listened attentively to the remarks of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Latham), and like the honorable member for Werriwa (Mr. Lazzarini) came to the conclusion that his speech was designed merely to make a show of real opposition to the Government, and thereby placate the supporters of his party outside this chamber. The alleged Leader of the United party (Mr. Lyons) is absent, and perhaps there is a feeling amongst supporters of the Nationalist party that enough ginger has not Been put into the debates in this chamber since the change of leadership. The absence of the honorable member for Wilmot presented an opportunity to his deputy to make a show of hostility to the Government in order to be able to claim that the Nationalists are the parliamentary Opposition. It is obvious, however that he is engaged in a sham fight, for the purpose of creating the impression that the Opposition parties are resisting the Government in some directions, when actually they are very pleased with the policy if has proposed. One may reasonably predict that the Opposition, having forced a so-called Labour government to adopt measures which, after all, are of Nationalist origin, will not show much consideration to its catspaws, should a later opportunity present itself to remove the Ministry from power, because the plums of office will be just as tempting to them as they are to those now enjoying them.
- The honorable member held on to office for a long time.

- That may be so in the honorable member's opinion; I am just as good a judge of political tactics as is the honorable member, and I knew which was the proper and fitting time to act, particularly when the demand for my resignation was being made by the avowed enemies of Labour. I can claim, however, that I rely on my own judgment in such matters, and I hope that I shall never have to take any advice from the Opposition or accept their policy while I am associated with the Labour movement.

speech.para: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to the policy of the Bruce Page Government, of which he was a member, and emphasized the need for scrapping all our industrial legislation. He put up the case that was advanced at the last general elections. He claimed that while the plan might effect a certain redress of the position, it was not sufficient; that, sooner or later, Parliament would have to accept entirely the proposals which his party had put before the people at the last general election. One must be quite honest, and admit that there has been a definite measure of consistency in the attitude of the honorable gentleman. He and his party went to the poll with a certain programme. ' The Bruce-Page Government urged that u certain course should be taken. It argued that what it termed the restrictions and hampering alleged to be caused by industrial awards should be abolished. The members of the Labour party, who then formed the Opposition, contended that such a course would throw the workers into the open economic ring, where they would be exploited in all directions. Consequently, the proposals of honorable members opposite were strenuously resisted by the Labour party.

talk.start.para: - The Bruce-Page Government desired the abolition of the Federal Arbitration Court, leaving arbitration to the State tribunals.

- That was the Nationalist policy, but we had had at the time an experience of what would happen under such an arrangement. The Nationalist Government in New South Wales had already brought about the abolition of rural awards, and various Nationalist organizations in other States were endeavouring to achieve similar reactionary objectives, so that it was obvious that their intention was to scrap all industrial tribunals, Federal and State. I point out - and this cannot be denied by any supporter of the Nationalist party - that when a policy is formulated at the Nationalist conventions that are held . annually, no line of demarcation is drawn between Commonwealth and State as regards the operation of the Nationalist policy, and it is the bounden duty of the party's representatives in Parliament, whether in the Federal or State arena, to endeavour to apply the policy in their own sphere where it is practicable. If that is not so, why are annual conferences held to formulate the general policy of the party? Just before the last general election took place, the Nationalist party was endeavouring to apply to the federal arena a policy that it had already applied in the State of New South Wales. [Quorum formed.]

speech.para: The utterances of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Latham) this afternoon are in line with the objectives of the Nationalist party. I am not complaining that honorable members opposite hold certain opinions; I am contrast ing their attitude with the attitude of the gentlemen who at present occupy the treasury bench. Members of this Parliament went to the polls at the last general election on a definite issue, the retention of the principle of arbitration. I. might very appositely read a passage taken from the Prime Minister's speech, when he appealed to the supporters of Labour in his then role of Leader of the Opposition. He stated -

quote.para: The proposal you are being ashed to vote for by the present reactionary Government is nothing less than the abolition in one fell swoop of our federal arbitration system, the system which has grown out of the misery and oppression of the workers; the system which our fathers won for us, and the humanitarian statesmen have given us, building it up, act upon act.

speech.para: That conclusively proves that the main issue on which the elections were fought was the retention or abolition of the principle of arbitration. The result of the general election is well known. Labour was returned with an overwhelming' majority. Naturally, it was expected by those who supported the Labour party that the new Government would be the staunch custodian of arbitration in all its aspects, and would not depart from the principles enunciated by the present Prime Minister when he made his appeal to. the workers for their support. Yet, after eighteen months of office, the Government has definitely departed from its pledge, and betrayed the trust reposed in them by the workers. The provisions of the 'bill that is now before the House cut right across the principle of arbitration, in a ruthless fashion, and will do what Labour has always bitterly opposed, by giving to a Minister the right to determine what wages and conditions shall prevail in industry.

The Leader of the Opposition is certainly in what must be to him a most agreeable position. A so-called Labour party has destroyed the very thing which it was elected to defend, and which he has always endeavoured to destroy. When next there is an appeal to the country, the honorable gentleman will be able to hold up against the present supporters of this Government decisions of which they have approved which are entirely contrary to the pledges upon which Labour was returned to office eighteen mon ti is ago.

The Opposition is now in a very favorable position, and if the Deputy Leader gave free expression to his feelings he would declare himself much ' pleased at the turn which events have taken. This so-called Labour Government has disregarded its promise to the electors that the salaries of public servants and others under semi-government control now covered by Federal or State awards should be determined by arbitration. It has arbitrarily cut back the basic wage, and departed from- the policy previously adopted in arriving at that wage. The late Mr. Justice Higgins, in the Harvester judgment, laid down a formula for the determination of the basic wage. How jealously that principle has been safeguarded by Labour. Tear after year, Labour organizations have endeavoured to improve that formula by bringing it up to modern standards. Even during my short term as a member of the Government, representations were frequently made by the trade unions to the effect that the basic wage should not be determined solely on the statistics made available to the Government. Many unions expressed the view that the scope of the Statistician's inquiries was much too circumscribed; that the data on which he worked did not allow justice to be done to the workers. At that time the Government was anxious to investigate the subject exhaustively, in order that the interests of the workers should be safeguarded; but now it has changed its views entirely, and jettisoned the formula altogether. I suppose that the services of Professor Giblin will not be needed any longer when this measure has gone through, as no statistical inquiry of any kind will be required to determine the index figures for the basic wage of the salaries of public servants. The Government has decided to take off the Â£34 cost of living allowance, and then superimpose other reductions. We hear a good deal about constitutional practice in these matters. I am given to understand that, while, according to regulations, it is not proper to grant cost of living allowances retrospectively, a reduction of that allowance is to be given retrospective application. Time after time the unions have asked that their claims should have retrospective applica tion, but have been ruled out of court on the grounds that the Constitution did not permit of it. Now, when it suits this Labour Government to apply a reduction retrospectively, the Constitution is thrown aside. Perhaps this is being done because it is thought that the trade unions have not sufficient money to fight an action against the Government through the courts.

Not only is the Government going to interfere arbitrarily with wages in a general sense; it proposes also to save Â£1,000,000 from what is termed " miscellaneous expenditure ". I hope that when the bill reaches the committee stage details will be given as tq, what " miscellaneous expenditure " really comprises. Embodied in it, no doubt are many concessions that have been won by the Public Service, merely because they have been able, by using their numerical and financial strength, to see that justice was done to them. It is remarkable that a Labour government, which owes its existence to the strength of trade unionism, should now be the destroying agent in this matter. Obviously, the Government has accepted entirely the policy of the Nationalist party. That is why the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Latham) concluded his remarks this afternoon by saying that he would support all the proposals embodied in this plan. His conscience enables him to do so, as they are Nationalist proposals.

- Time alone will determine whether those are or are not Labour governments. It will be a ease of history repeating itself. Hud the proper treatment will he meted out to those who have abandoned their pledges.

The Deputy Leader of the Country party (Mr. Paterson) went to great pains to justify the reduction of wages proposed by this measure; there seemed to be nothing else in his mind. Vicary with ?169,000; Amy Vickery with ?53,000; Austin Howard Smith with ?20,000. " So I could go on through the list. There are the McIlwraiths with ?58,000; Sir J. Further on in the list there is Rebecca Smith Hill, who has ?39,000. There is also Laura Marie Hill, who is fairly poor, having ?43,326. There is Saunders, with ?100,000; McPhillamy with ?50,000. speech.para: Mr. Lang: Yes.
Those are the unfortunate bondholders for whom the Deputy Leader of the Country party (Mr. Paterson) is so much concerned.

talk.start.para: - Nonsense; I referred to the bondholders who drew less than ?100 a year as income from their investments.

- Right throughout this discussion piteous pleas have been made by honorable members opposite on behalf of the bondholders, while not one word has been said in defence of those whom I, and those who support me, represent.

- The honorable member says we are misguided. Well, I do not desire ever to be guided by him, or by those belonging to the party he represents. If he cares or dares to challenge our interest in Australia and our regard for its welfare, let me tell him that my people were in this country, building it up, long before he ever thought of coming here. 1 will not subscribe to his proposals for bringing about in Australia the conditions which existed in Scotland or elsewhere, and I do not propose meekly to accept his declaration that those of us in this corner have no regard for Australia.
